attributes.name: Event 2: Welcome to the Pit Stop!
Bone Crest-Eater Figurine of Wondrous Power

attribs.name: repeating_vehicle-systems_-NDYCqNKPeuP40Az96ta_description
attribs.current: As a swift action, a monowheel enercycle’s pilot can lean back, kick the throttle, and attempt a DC 20 Piloting check to launch the enercycle into the air for a short distance. On a success, the enercycle jumps 5 feet into the air across a distance of 10 feet; the enercycle ignores difficult terrain, rough terrain, and objects for that distance, as appropriate. The following round, the monowheel enercycle’s pilot takes a –4 penalty to Piloting checks. After launching, a monowheel enercycle can’t launch again for 1d4 rounds.

attribs.name: vehicle_dimensions
attribs.current: 4 ft. wide, 5 ft. long, 3 ft. high

attribs.name: vehicle_dimensions
attribs.current: 10 ft. wide, 15 ft. long, 5 ft. high

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The olghuth attacks PCs in the water first, followed by those on the rocks or ruins, with a preference for sapient organics. If no PCs are in the water, the olghuth attacks PCs in the boat.
Morale Made reckless by pain and hunger, the olghuth fights to the death. If the PCs flee on their boat, the olghuth follows for 2 rounds before realizing it can’t keep up and giving up the chase.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDYFjBv9bRaZXuW0ONX_description
attribs.current: As a standard action, an olghuth can scream in anguish. Each creature within 30 feet of the olghuth takes 11d6 sonic damage and is shaken for 1d4 rounds. A creature that succeeds at a DC 17 Will save takes half damage and reduces the shaken condition to 1 round. An olghuth can use this ability every [[1d6]] (1d6) rounds.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDYG0Snv3pMxBvpJVq0_description
attribs.current: As a ranged attack, an olghuth can heave a gob of caustic mucous with a range increment of 30 feet and the sicken critical hit effect.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDYG8VJBz2kEVfO3gYU_description
attribs.current: After eating a creature with an Intelligence of 6 or higher who died within the last 24 hours, an olghuth gains the ability to speak Aklo for a number of minutes equal to the CR of the consumed creature. During this time, the olghuth becomes euphoric and can’t use agonized wail.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDYGGrKI64MCsVHZcR1_description
attribs.current: As a full action, an olghuth can move up to double its speed. Each creature and vehicle the olghuth is adjacent to at any point during its movement takes 2d6+10 slashing damage from the olghuth’s razor sharp fins and spines. A creature that succeeds at a DC 17 Reflex save takes half damage.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDYJPn7oGuavZ3zFcow_description
attribs.current: A sagolath’s hooked tentacles have the anchoring weapon special property. The DC to escape a sagolath’s hooked tentacles increases by 1 for each additional tentacle anchored to the target (up to a maximum DC of 28).

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDYJRh9tyqDP5pETQgg_description
attribs.current: A sagolath is so immense that it functions as a starship (and thus engages only in starship combat). It has no crew, but it can take engineer, gunner, pilot, and science officer actions (one of each, in the appropriate phase) using the bonuses, level, and ranks listed above. Modifiers for its size, speed, and manoeuvrability have already been factored into its statistics. Use the following table to determine the effects when a sagolath takes critical damage.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDYJT7ve4oC8PGBoSYs_description
attribs.current: A sagolath’s hooked tentacles inject a powerful poisonous gas into anything it strikes. If the sagolath deals Hull Point damage to an enemy ship, it releases this poison into the ship. At the end of the current gunnery phase, all creatures on the affected ship must attempt a DC 17 Fortitude saving throw or take a –2 penalty on all starship action skill checks during the following round. This is a poison effect.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDYJUxWHQbiKE1P0OZQ_description
attribs.current: During the gunnery phase, a sagolath can pull a ship it has anchored with one of its hooked tentacles closer with a special gunnery action. The sagolath attempts a gunnery check against the anchored ship’s AC. On a success, the ship is dragged 1 hex closer to the sagolath.

attribs.name: repeating_attack_-NDTV6RfVjSDi-W9sI4U_description
attribs.current:
Broad Arc
A weapon with this special property can fire in an arc adjacent to the one in which it was installed with a –2 penalty. A broad arc weapon can fire at only one target at a time.

attribs.name: repeating_attack_-NDTVBG8iZezZJg7ZT9r_description
attribs.current:
Broad Arc
A weapon with this special property can fire in an arc adjacent to the one in which it was installed with a –2 penalty. A broad arc weapon can fire at only one target at a time.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTU8HdF2Ht6JR9CEgB_description
attribs.current:
Each starship has a base frame that determines its size, manoeuvrability, starting weapon mounts, hull strength, room for expansion, and other capacities. Although two ships that use the same frame might look radically different, they both have some of these base statistics in common. The frame of a starship includes all life support and artificial gravity systems necessary to keep the crew (and any passengers) alive and comfortable. The starship’s frame is also built with a transponder that is essentially the ship’s “address” for standard system-wide and unlimited-range communications (see page 430); this transponder can be turned off, during which time the starship can’t send or receive messages, but neither can it be tracked down by conventional means.

The base frames below are organized by size (from smallest to largest) and cost in Build Points (with less expensive frames coming first within a size). In general, the size and expansion bay capacities of a base frame can’t be changed without a great deal of time and money (and the GM’s permission), so it can be more effective to just start over with a different base frame when upgrading those aspects of a starship.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUB6nckecBEZfTTst_description
attribs.current: The power core is the most important system on a ship, as it provides power to every other system. The table below lists the ship size each core is designed for, as well as the PCU it provides and its cost. Each Large and smaller ship has room for only a single power core by default, but Medium and Large starships can be fitted with an extra power core housing (see Expansion Bays on page 298). Huge starships can have up to two power cores, Gargantuan starships can have up to three, and Colossal starships can have up to four. Though some ships are exceptions to this standard, they are rare in design. A power core typically has a backup battery system for use in emergencies that can provide limited power—enough for life support, gravity, and comms (see page 430), but no other systems—for 2d6 days.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUDe2EZDq6uLITqv1_description
attribs.current:
Ships rely on conventional thrusters to move between locations in a system, to navigate the reaches of the Drift once they arrive there, to explore, and to engage in combat They are designed for ships of a specific size (specified in the Size column of the table below), and they can’t be installed in a ship of an incorrect size. The maximum speed of a starship’s thrusters either grants a bonus or imparts a penalty to Piloting checks to fly the vessel, as noted on the table below.

Thrusters are also used when landing on and taking off from a planet. Large and smaller Starships generally have little difficulty landing on and taking off from a planet with low gravity or standard gravity (unless there are atmospheric conditions such as high winds or storms). The GM determines whether or not a starship’s pilot must attempt a Piloting check to land a starship with a speed lower than 8 on a planet with high gravity, with failure meaning it might crash. Due to their sheer size, Huge and larger starships can’t land on planets, and must use shuttles or other means to ferry crew and goods to a planet and back.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUJnubZbs4TzqUeWO_description
attribs.current: Armour protects a ship from direct-fire weapons (see Type on page 303), deflecting their energy and preventing damage to critical ship systems. It grants an armour bonus to a ship's AC. Armor's cost depends on the bonus it grants and the ship's size category (for the purpose of this calculation, Tiny = 1, Small = 2, Medium = 3, Large = 4, etc.). Armor is a passive system and does not require any PCU to remain functional. It provides protection primarily through mass, which can affect a ship's manoeuvrability (making it harder to turn) and make it easier for opponents using tracking weapons to lock on to the ship— these effects are listed in the Special column of the table below.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUQfnU0TKxCaDUCmu_description
attribs.current:
A computer system functions in many ways as a ship’s brain. Most computers aboard starships have at least a rudimentary artificial personality, and while they can’t fully perform the duties of a crew member, they can assist crew members in various tasks. However, many spacefarers claim that over time, a starship’s computers can develop temperaments and personality quirks that set them apart from identical computers in other ships. A starship has a basic computer of a tier equal to half the starship’s tier (minimum 1); see the Computers skill on page 137 and Computers on page 213 for more information about how a starship computer can be hacked or upgraded. Which upgrades a crew can purchase for its starship computer is determined by the GM; some upgrades can be purchased with Build Points (see page 294).

While a starship’s computer is responsible for operating and managing a wide variety of starship systems at any given point in time, only a starship with an integrated control module (ICM) can aid the crew in starship combat (the basic computer listed on the table below is the only option that lacks an ICM). In general, an ICM adds a flat circumstance bonus to one or more starship combat checks, decided just before the check is attempted. An ICM has a number of nodes; each node grants its bonus to one starship combat check per round. Multiple nodes allow an ICM to influence multiple starship combat checks in a round, but they do not allow a computer to add multiple bonuses to the same starship combat check.

The cost of an ICM for the starship’s computer is equal to the bonus it grants squared, multiplied by its number of nodes. ICMs can be purchased only with Build Points, not with credits.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUTndbbygYLDeVPSM_description
attribs.current: Common crew quarters are the most basic type. They consist of simple bunks (sometimes folding out from the side of a hallway) or other similarly austere places to rest. Crew members who sleep in common quarters usually keep their personal possessions in a footlocker. Common crew quarters also include a communal bathroom (which includes a military-style shower) and a tiny galley (big enough to prepare only the most basic of meals). Starships with crews numbering in the dozens or hundreds often have massive barracks where crew members sleep in shifts.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUVxudcw6-9ZnG9nC_description
attribs.current: Defensive countermeasures systems protect a ship from tracking weapons such as missiles, and they make it difficult for enemies using sensors to get a solid reading on the ship. They do this via a complicated suite of electronic sensors and broadcasting equipment that’s designed to jam enemy sensors and create false readings. These systems grant a bonus to a ship’s TL (see page 320); the bonus, PCU usage, and cost are listed in the table below.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUZfIAGrQ7t5zygh7_description
attribs.current:
These engines let you travel to and from the Drift (see page 290). The better the engine rating, the faster you can reach distant destinations. Drift engines have a PCU requirement and a maximum frame size. The cost in Build Points is based on the starship’s size category (for the purposes of this calculation, Tiny = 1, Small = 2, Medium = 3, Large = 4, and so on). See the table below for the statistics of the various Drift engines.

For a starship to engage its Drift engines to either enter or exit the Drift, its conventional thrusters must be turned off for 1 minute.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUp4qB0pQNqJlm5U3_description
attribs.current:
Sensors function as a starship’s eyes and ears, allowing a crew to see what’s in the space around the ship, whether planetary bodies, other ships, a dangerous asteroid field, or some monstrosity from the depths of space. Sensors are a combination of video cameras, multispectrum scanners, radar arrays, signal interceptors, and optical telescopes. In starship combat, short-range sensors have a range of 5 hexes, medium-range sensors have a range of 10 hexes, and long-range sensors have a range of 20 hexes. All sensors have a skill modifier that applies to any skill used in conjunction with them. Sensors require an operational power core to function, but they consume a negligible amount of PCU.

Sensors operate in two modes: passive or active. In passive mode, sensors automatically scan the ship’s surroundings. Passive sensors detect visible or unhidden objects in a 360-degree field around the ship at a range of up to twice the sensors’ range category while in space or in the Drift (no skill check required), though local conditions may affect their range. However, gravitational forces and atmospheric conditions limit starship sensors to a range of 250 feet on most planets, and their range might be further limited by terrain, at the GM’s discretion.

Active sensors are far more discerning, and they are required if the science officer wishes to scan enemy vessels and learn details about them during starship combat (see page 325). The modifier listed in the table below applies to some checks attempted by the science officer in starship combat as specified in the science officer’s actions (see page 324). Active sensors can discern information about a target up to five times the sensors’ range away from the ship, but such checks take a penalty of –2 for each range increment beyond the first to the target. For example, if short-range sensors (range = 5 hexes) were used against a target 12 hexes away, the check would take a –4 penalty.

Outside of starship combat, a crew member can use sensors to scan a planet the starship is orbiting, attempting a Computers check (applying the sensors’ modifier) to learn basic information about the planet’s composition and atmosphere. The DC for this check is usually 15, but it can be altered at the GM’s discretion to account for mitigating factors or complications. A crew member can also use the starship’s active sensors to attempt Perception checks to examine the surrounding area as if she were standing outside the starship, using her own senses (such as darkvision), but adding the sensors’ modifier as a circumstance bonus to the check.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUszU-soaoyV6QGUA_description
attribs.current:
Regeneration: 8/min.

While almost every ship has simple navigational shielding to prevent damage from tiny bits of debris, this protection does little to stop a starship from being damaged by lasers, missiles, and larger impacts. To defend against such threats, a ship has energy shields, though these shields don't count as force effects. Projectors mounted around the ship create a barrier that absorbs damage from attacks. Each attack reduces the number of Shield Points (SP) in a given arc until that arc's shields are depleted, after which point all further damage in that arc reduces the ship's Hull Points. See Damage on page 304 for more information. Shield Points regenerate over time and can eventually be used again, but this regeneration occurs only when the ship is not in combat or otherwise taking damage. Shields must be attached to a functional power core in order to regenerate; the rate of regeneration is listed in the table below.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUdjJMhoSWdFItSYR_description
attribs.current: When properly reinforced to absorb the strain, an expansion bay along a starship’s aft or sides can house additional thrusters and fuel tanks (the thrusters must be purchased separately and be an appropriate size for the starship) as well as separate fuel tanks. During starship combat, the pilot can activate these additional thrusters before moving the starship during the helm phase as part of their crew action. When activated, the additional boosters increase the starship’s speed by an amount equal to the boosters’ listed speed divided by 4 (rounded down) and increase the DC of Piloting checks to perform stunts that round by an equal amount. The boosters’ supplemental fuel supply can power them for 5 rounds, after which the thrusters need 24 hours to recharge from the ship’s power core. A starship can have only one such additional booster active at a time.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUg9JvFkO3qAoaN3-_description
attribs.current: Unconverted expansion bays count as cargo holds. A cargo hold can contain approximately 25 tons of goods, with no item being larger than Large. A starship with multiple cargo holds can hold larger objects; usually 4 contiguous cargo holds are required to hold Huge objects and 8 for Gargantuan objects. These size restrictions can be overridden at the GM’s discretion.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTUhVYzWmi7f4AT9Pb_description
attribs.current: By dedicating additional space to the thrusters and related systems, a starship can vastly decrease the amount of time needed for its thrusters to warm up and engage. The thrusters primer reduces the time needed to start the thrusters from 1 minute per size category to 1 round per size category, allowing even immense starships to finish the ignition sequence in less than a minute. During the first engineering phase of starship combat, a thrusters primer grants a short boost to a starship’s propulsion, automatically increasing the starship’s speed by 2 as though the engineer had used the divert action to direct power to the engines.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The furious fire elementals rage blindly for the first round of combat, then attack the enercycle for the following 2 rounds. On the fourth round, the elementals turn on Penvo, killing him at the end of the fifth round.
Morale When one fire elemental remains and it’s reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer, that elemental flees. If there’s an opening in the force field (thanks to the PCs), it flees through that gap and into the stands, injuring spectators during its flight. Otherwise, it flees down the track.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNiWZfpS1ITrnZQx7a_description
attribs.current: A fire elemental's slams deal half fire damage and half bludgeoning damage. In addition, on a critical hit, the fire elemental's strieks deal an amount of burn damage based on the creatures CR, as listed in the table below.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNj4JDI5RuuHtcYpuS_description
attribs.current: A security robot's weapons are integrated into its frame and can't be disarmed.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNj4JDI5RuuHtcYpuT_description
attribs.current: Once every 1d4 rounds as a standard action, a patrol-class security robot can shoot an arc of electricity at up to four creatures within 40 feet (no two of which can be more than 30 feet apart). This arc deals 1d8 electricity damage to each target (Reflex DC 13 half).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNj4JDI5RuuHtcYpuU_description
attribs.current: A patrol-class security robot's nanites heal it, restoring a number of Hit Points per hour equal to its CR (4 Hit Points per hour for most security robots). Once per day as a full action, a patrol-class security robot can restore 3d8 Hit Points to itself or any touched construct with the technological subtype.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat Mishori begins by summoning a small fire elemental. He then uses his damage-dealing spells as appropriate, targeting the nearest PC. If one of his robots is near destruction, he casts make whole to repair it.
Morale Mishori attempts to flee when reduced to 20 Hit Points or fewer, leaving his robots behind to continue the fight.

attribs.current: Castrovelian, Common, Ignan; Limited Telepathy 30 ft.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NCVinTOZdTnPRFCmLQM_description
attribs.current:
Mishori detects the surface thoughts of intelligent Creatures around him. The amount of information revealed depends on how long Mishori studies a particular area or Target.

1st Round: Mishori detects the presence or absence of thoughts from conscious Creatures that have Intelligence scores of at least 1 (or an Intelligence Modifier of –5) or higher.

2nd Round: Mishori detects the number of thinking minds and the Intelligence score (or modifier) of each. If the highest Intelligence score is 26 (or a Modifier of +8) or higher and at least 10 points higher than Mishori's own Intelligence score (or 5 points higher than his own Intelligence modifier), he is stunned for 1 round and the spell ends. This spell doesn’t let Mishori determine the location of the thinking minds if he can’t see the Creatures whose thoughts he is detecting.

3rd Round: Mishori can read the surface thoughts of any mind in the area. A Target who succeeds at its Will save prevents Mishori from reading its thoughts, and he must cast detect thoughts again to have another chance. Creatures of Animal intelligence (an Intelligence score of 1 or 2 or an Intelligence Modifier of –4 or lower) have simple, instinctual thoughts.

Each round, Mishori can turn to detect thoughts in a new area. The spell can penetrate barriers, but 3 feet of dirt or wood, 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of Common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or any force field blocks it.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NCVipqWznZIvhurKB8e_target
attribs.current: One Humanoid Creature of CR 3 or Lower

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NCVipqWznZIvhurKB8e_description
attribs.current: This spell short-circuits the mind of a Humanoid Creature with a CR of 3 or lower so that it is dazed (unable to take actions, but taking no penalty to AC). Humanoids of CR 4 or higher are not affected. After a Creature has been dazed by this spell, it is immune to it for 1 minute.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVivWLRlEmujJ9HWVQ_target
attribs.current: One Object of Up to 6 Bulks or One Construct of Any Size

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVivWLRlEmujJ9HWVQ_description
attribs.current:
This spell repairs damaged objects and constructs, restoring 5d6 Hit Points. If the Object has the Broken condition, this condition is removed if the Object is restored to at least half its original Hit Points. All of the pieces of an Object must be present for this spell to function. A Construct can benefit from this spell only once per day.

Make whole can fix destroyed Magic Items, and it restores the magic properties of the item if your Technomancer level is at least twice the item’s level. Items with Charges (such as batteries) and single-use items (such as potions and grenades) can’t be repaired in this way. When you cast make whole on a Construct, the spell bypasses any immunity to magic as if the spell did not allow Spell Resistance.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVix3zJsuZm6gG5FvX_description
attribs.current:
This spell summons an Extraplanar Creature (typically an Elemental, Magical Beast Native to another plane, or Outsider, but also occasionally even Extraplanar constructs). The summoned Creature appears where Mishori designates and acts immediately on his turn. It Attacks Mishori's opponents to the best of its ability. If Mishori can communicate with the Creature, he can direct it to not Attack, to Attack particular enemies, or to perform Other Actions.

When Mishori gains this spell as a spell known, select four Creatures from the appropriate list in Table 8: Summon Creature for each level at which he can cast this spell. For
In place of a single selection, Mishori can choose a Creature from a lower-level Summoning list; doing so allows him the option of Summoning multiple such Creatures at a time. Each time Mishori gains a character level, he can change these selections.

Mishori can gain summon Creature a second time at the highest Spell Level he knows, selecting four additional appropriate Creatures at each level he can cast this spell.

Mishori choose which of the selected Creatures he summons each time he casts the spell.

1st: When Mishori casts summon Creature as a 1st-level spell, he summons one Creature from his selection of Creatures from the 1st-level Summoning list.

2nd: When Mishori casts summon Creature as a 2nd-level spell, he summons one Creature from his selection of Creatures from the 2nd-level Summoning list. If the chosen Creature is from a lower-level Summoning list, Mishori summons three such Creatures instead.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVj2fkvDcmiLFGwAWZ_description
attribs.current:
Mishori touches a Target with a device he's holding that uses electricity, requiring a melee Attack against the target’s EAC. Alternatively, Mishori can instead touch an electrical device a Target is wearing (or a Target that is an electrical device, such as a robot) with his hand, gaining a +2 bonus to his Attack roll. Either way, if Mishori's Attack hits, the electrical device surges out of Control, dealing 4d6 electricity damage to his Target.

Casting this spell doesn’t provoke Attacks of opportunity.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVj4OJ7Nj55Zxk2uKt_target
attribs.current: Up to Three Creatures, No Two of Which Can Be More than 15 ft. Apart; See Text

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVj4OJ7Nj55Zxk2uKt_description
attribs.current:
Mishori fires two Missiles of magical energy that strike Targets unerringly (the Creatures must still be valid targets) and deal 1d4+1 force damage each. Mishori can’t Target specific parts of a Creature, and objects are not damaged by the spell.

Mishori can Target a single Creature or several Creatures, but each missile can strike only one Creature. Mishori must designate Targets before he attempts to overcome Spell Resistance or roll damage.

Mishori can cast this spell as a Full Action. If Mishori does, he fires three Missiles instead of two.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVj63N46x83lSDQole_description
attribs.current: Mishori collects the heat generated by nearby bodies and devices and vent it outward in a thermal wave, dealing 2d8 fire damage to Creatures and objects in the area.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVjHCyNYPbNJYM-pME_description
attribs.current: Mishori detects all magic Spells, effects, items, and objects (including those on or affecting Creatures you can see), as well as Hybrid Items, in the area. Mishori can’t detect magical traps in this way, as they are created with additional magic that wards them from this Common spell. Each round Mishori concentrates on the same area, he can determine if one magic source he detects is from a spell, magic item, or other Effect, and the caster level (or item level) of the Effect. Mishori can’t determine if there are magic sources in areas he can’t see, or if there was a magic source in an area at one time but that has since expired.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NCVjIxlv5bdL59FUmAp_description
attribs.current:
Token Spells are often some of the first minor changes that spellcasters produce when they begin experimenting with magic. Once cast, token spell enables Mishori to perform simple magical effects for 1 hour. The effects are minor and have severe limitations. Mishori can slowly lift one item of light bulk. Mishori can alter items in a 1-foot cube each round, colouring, cleaning, soiling, cooling, warming, or flavouring them. Mishori can create small objects, but they look artificial and are extremely fragile (they can’t be used as tools or weapons). Mishori can illuminate an Object to shed Dim Light in a 30-foot radius.

Token spell lacks the power to duplicate any other spell effects. Any actual change to an Object (beyond Moving, cleaning, or soiling it) persists for only 1 hour.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The bloodbrothers remain near the stanchion, suspecting it’s important, and attack everyone who nears.
Morale A bloodbrother flees when it has a victim trapped within its rib cage prison. If unable to retreat, it fights to the death to retain control of its meal.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNlSHMEPs-iafNrQMX_description
attribs.current: A bloodbrother’s body generates intense cold, dealing 1d6 cold damage to any creature that hits it with a natural weapon or unarmed strike and to any creature the bloodbrother hits with its slam attack. A creature that begins its turn grappled by a bloodbrother also takes this damage.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNlSHMEPs-iafNrQMY_description
attribs.current: If a bloodbrother begins its turn grappling a creature that is Large or smaller, it can attempt a grapple combat maneuver as a standard action to transfer the creature into its rib cage prison. A creature in a bloodbrother’s rib cage prison has the grappled condition. As a reaction, a bloodbrother can force a creature in its rib cage prison to attempt a DC 15 Fortitude saving throw; on a failed save, the creature takes 1 point of Constitution damage. Any round that a creature in its rib cage prison takes this Constitution damage, the bloodbrother gains fast healing 5 for that round only; the above statistics assume a bloodbrother has a Small animal with a current Constitution score of 5 (its maximum Constitution score is 10) trapped in its rib cage prison at the beginning of combat. A bloodbrother can have only one creature in its rib cage prison at a time; if it imprisons a new creature, it must release the creature currently in its rib cage. Releasing a creature does not require an action.

attribs.name: other_abilities
attribs.current: Artificial Intelligence (Exocortex), Custom Rig (Cybernetic Augmentation [Brain]), Easily Augmented, Mechanic Tricks (Energy Shield [9 HP, 4 Minutes], Overcharge), Skin Mimic

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: Clearweave I, Live Glass Blade with 2 Batteries (20 Charges each), Voltaic Anchor Pistol with 2 Batteries (40 Charges each), Mk 1 Web Grenades (2); Augmentations Azimuth Optical Laser, Minimal Speed Suspension, Standard Darkvision Capacitors

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
Before Combat Two techno-terrorists begin atop the highest platform, and two begin on the middle platform; they activate their energy shields before combat when they see the PCs approach.
During Combat The NextStep agents use their web grenades to hamper the PCs, then switch to their pistol for as long as possible, using overcharge to increase the damage. They aim to render the PCs unconscious, leaving them alive for forced “evolution.”
Morale These fanatics fight to the death.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDOhIDpR8k5qQugoKNI_description
attribs.current: As a move action, a techno-terrorist can designate and track a single foe, gaining a +2 bonus to attack rolls against that target.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDOhFSNiormLL3zCIlF_description
attribs.current: As a standard action, a techno-terrorist can cause a short in an electronic device, including most ranged energy weapons, melee weapons with the powered special property, or a single armour upgrade. This makes the device nonfunctional for 1 round. Overload doesn’t cause a locked door, safe, or other device to open, but it prevents anyone from opening it for 1 round. The techno-terrorist must be adjacent to the device to use this ability. If the techno-terrorist has an exocortex with the wireless hack ability, they can instead use this ability on any electronic device within range of their exocortex’s wireless hack. If the techno-terrorist uses overload on an item or armour upgrade in someone’s possession, the owner can attempt a Reflex saving throw to negate the effect (DC 15). Overload doesn’t affect androids, cybernetics, drones, powered armour, robots, or creatures with the technological subtype (all of which have shielding against this sort of attack), or items larger than Medium. Once a device has been successfully overloaded, a residual static charge prevents that device from being overloaded again for 1 minute.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The mercenaries fight at range, switching to melee when the PCs approach the stanchion. 
Morale When a strix mercenary is reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer, they take flight, firing their rifles from the air. If one strix is killed or all strix are reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer, they flee back to Qidel as a unit.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSa8KgtyBeASuBL2ng_description
attribs.current: As a full action, a strix mercenary can move up to twice their speed and make one attack, but their target must be a creature threatening an ally. Once the strix mercenary has used this ability, they cannot do so again until they have taken a 10-minute rest to regain Stamina Points.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: Lashunta Ringwear II (Mk 1 Thermal Capacitor), Rocket Rifle with 10 Mini-Rockets, Tactical Handaxe, Mk 1 Pulse Grenades (2), Tier 3 Excitants (2), Encrypted Credstick (3,000 credits)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSeHSv9v5RS7clooG5_description
attribs.current: A strix mercenary can help squad mates hit targets even if they're in the way. The strix mercenary gains Coordinated Shot as a bonus feat. The strix mercenary's allies gain the bonus even if they are providing cover to the target. If the strix mercenary already has that feat, they gain a bonus combat feat instead.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSeSjFbM4UarLO6KM2_description
attribs.current: Soldiers in large organizations, such as the Stewards, learn to fight effectively together in small squads. The strix mercenary has mastered these techniques, and their combat skills focus on aiding their allies. Half-elves epitomize the cooperative spirit this style taps into.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSegPbrzKZHkk246ac_description
attribs.current: A strix mercenary has a preferred fighting style that represents the type of soldier they are. Each fighting style is composed of various style techniques that the strix mercenary learns as they gain experience.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSeomP0noA69ZwRbZw_description
attribs.current: A strix mercenary learns a trick called a gear boost that make them better with a particular type of weapon or armour.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSfCrSZ6D2w0DrJiMB_description
attribs.current: Whenever they're wearing armour (including powered armour), a strix mercenary reduces their total armour check penalty by 1 (minimum 0) and total speed adjustment by 5 feet (minimum adjustment 0 feet). These benefits stack with similar effects, such as from the guard fighting style’s 1st-level style technique.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The strix sniper takes to the skies when the PCs approach. When reduced to 50 Hit Points or fewer, they throw down a smoke grenade to envelop at least one PC, land within the smoke, and use master of disguise to impersonate a PC to sow discord and confusion while their allies continue the assault. When their ruse is detected, they resume their attack.
Morale When a strix is reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer, they take flight, fighting at range from the air. If one strix is killed or all strix are reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer, they flee back to Qidel as a unit.

attribs.name: other_abilities
attribs.current: Nightborn, Operative Exploits (Debilitating Sniper, Master of Disguise), Specialization (spy), Tinkerer

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: Estex Suit III (Auto-Injector [Mk 2 Healing Serum], Mk 1 Thermal Capacitor), Advanced Semi-Auto Pistol with 24 Rounds, Tactical Knife, Triple Focus Rifle with 2 Batteries (40 Charges each), Smoke Grenades (2), Glove of Storing, Mk 2 Mindlink Circlet, Tier 3 Excitants (2), Encrypted Credstick (3,000 credits)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSczTi8ML7RcPXehaL_description
attribs.current: When a strix sniper succeeds at both the skill check and attack roll of their trick attack, they can make the target flat-footed or off-target until the beginning of their next turn. The strix sniper might learn exploits that grant them additional options for their debilitating trick, but they can select only one option each time they hit with a trick attack.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSdherVZNbN28e8Pkf_description
attribs.current: A strix sniper can trick or startle a foe and then attack when she drops her guard. As a full action, the strix sniper can move up to their speed. Whether or not the strix sniper moved, they can then make an attack with a melee weapon with the operative special property or with any small arm. Just before making their attack, attempt a Bluff, Intimidate, or Stealth check with a DC equal to 20 + the strix sniper's target’s CR. If the strix sniper succeeds at the check, they deal 4d8 additional damage and the target is flat-footed against their attack. The strix sniper can’t use this ability with a weapon that has the unwieldy special property or that requires a full action to make a single attack.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat Each carrion wheel attacks a different PC. 
Morale The carrion wheels fight to the death.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNmZarsmbEuUZrkdbw_description
attribs.current: A carrion wheel can adeptly ambush its prey while concealed. A carrion wheel that can act during a surprise round can take its full round of actions. It gains a +2 bonus to any attacks it makes during a surprise round.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNmZarsmbEuUZrkdbx_description
attribs.current: Toxic enzymes on the carrion wheel’s tentacles cause targets’ skin to erupt in painful rashes and excruciating, acid-filled boils. A creature hit by a carrion wheel’s tentacle attack is sickened for 1 round and develops boils (Fortitude DC 14 negates both effects). The next time the creature takes bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, the boils explode violently, dealing 2d8 acid damage to the target (no save) and 2d8 acid damage to each creature within 5 feet of the target (Reflex DC 14 for half). If not ruptured, the boils fade naturally after 10 minutes, and they can be removed magically with lesser remove condition. This ability is a disease effect.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNmZarsmbEuUZrkdby_description
attribs.current: A creature that briefly touches a carrion wheel (such as with an unarmed attack or most combat manoeuvres) is exposed to the carrion wheel’s inflame ability (Reflex DC 14 negates). Actions that involve longer contact, such as grapple combat manoeuvres, automatically expose the creature to the inflame ability with no Reflex save.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat Despite their anger, the competitors fight with improvised weapons (such as free weights) or their fists and deal nonlethal damage.
Morale If hit by a lethal attack or reduced to 5 Hit Points or fewer, a rally competitor surrenders.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: Flight Suit Stationwear, Pulsecaster Pistol with 1 Battery (20 Charges), Survival Knife

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSj06LIFN9BAWAjZsP_description
attribs.current: A rally competitor doesn’t treat improvised weapons or unarmed strikes as archaic. When wielded by a rally competitor, an improvised weapon has the analog, nonlethal, and thrown 10 feet traits, and the knockdown critical hit effect. Some objects, like paper or a pillow, are too light or soft to wield in this way while others, like a mug or plate, are destroyed on a successful hit. The GM determines which objects fall into these categories.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The scuttling toxin fights from afar, spitting poisoning at as many creatures as possible.
Morale The scuttling toxin flees either after 3 rounds, when all PCs are poisoned, or if reduced to 40 Hit Points or less. If confronted a second time or more, the creature continues these tactics. After fleeing, the scuttling toxin proceeds with its mission to poison the water supply.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSkovNMaTKoYSRhd-9_description
attribs.current: As a move action, a scuttling toxin can curse a single target within 30 feet that it can see. The target must attempt a DC 17 Will saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes a –2 circumstance penalty to its saving throws against poison. A creature who succeeds at the save is immune to the same scuttling toxin’s baleful glare for 24 hours. The scuttling toxin can only curse 1 creature at a time with baleful glare; if a new creature is targeted the previous target is no longer cursed. This is a curse effect.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSkovNMaTKoYSRhd-9_effect
attribs.current: Target takes -2 circumstance penalty to its saving throws against poison.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSkovNMaTKoYSRhd-9_save_effect
attribs.current: Negates and immune to its effect for 24 hours.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSkr8W8Vp4Rcnb6NU1_description
attribs.current: As a ranged attack, a scuttling toxin can spew a ball of poison at a single target with a range increment of 40 feet. A creature damaged by this attack are exposed to gutrot.

attribs.name: race
attribs.current: Dwarf, Halfling, Sarcesian, or Ysoki Soldier

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The pirates activate their frenzied fighting and fight in melee with their curve blades, placing themselves between Captain Cutter and the PCs. The pirates resort to ranged combat only if they’re unable to get into melee. 
Morale A pirate surrenders when reduced to 10 Hit Points or fewer, or when Captain Cutter surrenders.

attribs.name: languages
attribs.current: Common and one of Dwarven, Halfling, Sarcesian, or Ysoki

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: Squad Defiance Series, Azimuth Artillery Laser with 1 Battery (20 Charges), Carbon Steel Curve Blade, Encrypted Credstick (1,000 Credits)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSmr1V9CJEJuRwf6j3_description
attribs.current: A reaper pirate has a preferred fighting style that represents the type of soldier they are. Each fighting style is composed of various style techniques that the reaper pirate learns as they gain experience.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSn6Ei3F7spZHa55Zy_description
attribs.current: The wrathful warrior style draws upon the reaper pirate's emotions—specifically their rage and wrath—to enable devastating attacks. A reaper pirate may have trained themself to intentionally overload their fight-or-flight adrenaline response, or may just come from a long line of berserker warriors.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSnIB0HQMftXWZ-JZW_description
attribs.current:
As a swift action, a reaper pirate can enter a frenzy that empowers their attacks and deadens them to fear and pain for a number of rounds equal to 1d4 + 2. While frenzied, the reaper pirate gains a +2 bonus to melee damage rolls and Will saves, as well as a –1 penalty to AC.

While frenzied, the reaper pirate can’t use any ability that requires patience or concentration, such as spellcasting. or any Charisma-, Dexterity-, or Intelligence-based skills except Acrobatics, Intimidate, and Piloting. The reaper pirate can’t use this ability again until after their frenzy ends and they rest for 10 minutes to regain Stamina Points.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSnIB0HQMftXWZ-JZW_mods
attribs.current:
+2 to damage
+2 to will
-1 to armor

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat Captain Cutter fights with her pistol, using quick dispiriting taunt to trigger her fearmonger ability. She pauses her assault only long enough to use inspiring boost on an ally or drink a healing serum.
Morale Captain Cutter surrenders when reduced to 20 Hit Points or fewer.

attribs.name: other_abilities
attribs.current: Berate, Envoy Improvisations (Inspiring Boost [15 SP], Quick Dispiriting Taunt)

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: Freebooter Armour II, Hook Sword, Frostbite-Class Zero Pistol with 2 Batteries (20 Charges each), Mk 2 Healing Serums (2), Encrypted Credstick (4,000 credits)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSq0tMXAZpm0WLzI7L_description
attribs.current: As a reaction when an ally within 30 feet would fail a saving throw against an emotion, fear, or mind-affecting effect, Captain Cutter can spend 1 RP to berate that ally for their weakness and insubordination. That ally rerolls their saving throw against the triggering effect. They must use the results of this reroll, even if it is worse.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDSq23sWPNz243BneRg_description
attribs.current: Captain Cutter deals an additional 1d6 damage when she hits a shaken creature with a melee or ranged attack.

attribs.name: speed
attribs.current: 30 ft., Burrow 10 ft., Fly 30 ft. (Ex, Average)

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat Each diatha viciously attacks the nearest creature. 
Morale These diathas are trained to fight to the death.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNr743mYWuj0bDeqI1_description
attribs.current: A diatha elder can hover as a swift action or part of a full action without needing to attempt an Acrobatics check. It can avoid falling damage as if it had perfect manoeuvrability.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNr743mYWuj0bDeqI2_description
attribs.current: While the diatha has 20 or fewer Hit Points, its energy-dense flesh becomes unstable. If, while in this state, the diatha takes acid, electricity, fire, piercing, slashing, or sonic damage, or uses its explosive charge ability, it dies, exploding in a 10-foot-radius burst, dealing 2d6 fire damage and causing the burning condition, dealing 1d4 fire damage (Reflex DC 13 for half damage and no burning condition).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NBNr743mYWuj0bDeqI3_description
attribs.current: While the diatha has 20 or fewer Hit Points, as a full action, the creature can move up to double its speed and make a bite attack. Its detonate ability then triggers.

attribs.name: race
attribs.current: Male Human Vanguard (Starfinder Character Operations Manual 50)

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The cultists lob grenades from cover atop their crate barricades, then switch to their pistols. When the PCs reach them, or when the PCs defeat Olanim, the cultists fight in melee, using their entropic strike. They use Shield Block whenever possible. 
Morale The cultists fight to the death.

attribs.name: other_abilities
attribs.current: Entropic Pool (Maximum 5), Reactive 1/Day, Vanguard Aspects (Cascade—Embodiment), Vanguard Disciplines (Energize, Evasion)

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: Golemforged Plating III (Filtered Rebreather), Field Riot Shield, Corona Laser Pistol with 2 Batteries (20 Charges each), Fangblade with 2 Batteries (20 Charges each), Mk 2 Incendiary Grenades (2)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDT7n1ztlFOV5IlDVZ-_description
attribs.current: As a killer cultist learns to exert finer control over their entropic strike, they can enhance it to devastating effect.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat If Olanim hears the PCs approach, she casts flight on herself, grease on the nearby crates, and activates overlapping forms. She then hides behind the crate barrier until the PCs arrive. She opens combat with slow and hold person to hamper the PCs, then uses her damage dealing spells, infinite worlds, or flame pistol as the situation permits. She uses resist elements whenever possible. 
Morale Olanim is a fatalist who fights to the death.

attribs.name: other_abilities
attribs.current: Alternate Outcome 1/Day, Elven Magic, Infinite Worlds (3/Day, 170 feet, 7 Rounds), Paradigm Shifts (Overlapping Forms, Resist Elements)

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: D-Suit II, Corona Laser Pistol with 2 Batteries (20 Charges each), Tactical Knife, Encrypted Credstick (6,000 Credits)

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT8xW6k3JqZe6suO2S_description
attribs.current:
Olanim tinkers with the particles of magic surrounding one or more Targets to either allow them to slow a fall, gently rise or descend, or fly short or vast distances.

1st: When Olanim casts flight as a 1st-level spell, she can Target seven Medium or smaller Falling Objects or Creature at close range (40 feet). The Targets must all be within 20 feet of each other. A Large Creature or Object counts as two Medium Creatures or objects, a Huge Creature or Object counts as four Medium Creatures or objects, and so on. The affected Targets instantly fall slower, at a rate of just 60 feet per round (equivalent to the end of a fall from a few feet). The Targets take no damage upon landing while the spell is in Effect. This spell doesn’t affect charging or Flying Creatures.

For each Target, this casting of the spell lasts until that Target lands or 7 rounds (whichever happens first).

The 1st-level version of this spell can be cast as a Reaction, but when Olanim does so, she can’t take a Standard action on her next round.

2nd: When Olanim casts flight as a 2nd-level spell, she can Target herself or one willing or unconscious Creature or unattended Object (total weight up to 700 pounds or 70 bulk) at close range. The spell allows Olanim to move the Target up or down as she wishes. Each round as a Move Action, Olanim can mentally direct the Target up or down as much as 20 feet. Olanim can’t move the Target horizontally. A levitating Creature that Attacks with a melee or Ranged weapon finds itself increasingly unstable; the first Attack takes a –1 penalty to Attack rolls, the second a –2 penalty, and so on, to a maximum of –5. A full round spent Stabilizing allows the Creature to begin again at –1.

This casting of the spell lasts 7 minutes and is dismissible.

3rd: When Olanim casts flight as a 3rd-level spell, she can Target one willing or unconscious touched Creature and give it the power of flight. The Target can fly at a speed of 60 feet with average manoeuvreability. Flying while under this spell’s effects takes no more Concentration than walking, so the Target can Attack or cast Spells normally. The Target can Charge but not run, and it can’t carry aloft more weight than its Normal bulk limit. The Target gains a bonus to Acrobatics checks to fly equal to 3.
If this spell expires or is dispelled while the Target is aloft, the Target floats downward 60 feet per round for 1d6 rounds. If it reaches the ground in that amount of time, it lands safely. If not, it falls the rest of the distance, taking 1d6 damage per 10 feet fallen.
The spell lasts for 7 minutes.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT8ydfHWxqc3S3Xcnn_target
attribs.current: Up to 7 Creatures, no two of which can be more than 30 ft. apart

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT8ydfHWxqc3S3Xcnn_description
attribs.current: An affected Creature moves and Attacks at a drastically slowed rate. Creatures affected by this spell are staggered and can take only a single Move Action or Standard action each turn, but not both, and it can’t take full actions. A slowed Creature moves at half its Normal speed (round down to the next 5-foot increment). Multiple slow effects don’t stack. Slow counters and Negates haste.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT92ePc930P9cVAAPI_description
attribs.current: Olanim flings magical nanites that convert water vapour around her Target into deadly acid. Make a Ranged Attack roll against Olanim's target’s EAC. If Olanim hits, the Target takes 4d4 acid damage and it takes 5 additional acid damage at the end of its turn each round for the spell’s duration.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT94-dn62UrQFtQ5ud_description
attribs.current:
Olanim gathers mystical energy and blast it outward in a mighty wave originating from her fingertips, damaging and potentially knocking back her enemies. This spell deals 2d6 force damage to each Creature in the area unless it succeeds at a Reflex saving throw for half damage.

Additionally, the force from this spell effectively attempts to Bull Rush all Creatures in the area. Attempt a single Bull Rush Combat Manoeuvre, using her caster level + her Charisma Modifier as her Attack bonus. Compare the result to each target’s KAC + 8. If Olanim's successful, that Creature is knocked back 5 feet, plus 5 additional feet for every 5 by which her Attack exceeds the creature’s KAC + 8. If there is an obstacle in the way, the Creature stops at the obstacle instead.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT95BoazWhUqJ55pJq_description
attribs.current: The Target becomes Paralyzed and freezes in place. It is aware and breathes normally but can’t take any physical actions, even Speech. A held Creature can’t cast Spells. Each round on its turn, the Target can spend a Full Action to attempt a new saving throw to end the Effect. This does not provoke Attacks of opportunity. A winged Creature that is Paralyzed can’t flap its wings and falls. A swimmer can’t swim and may drown.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT96cv4OeSVVK76oCZ_description
attribs.current:
Olanim exposes targets to churning entropy which turns parts of their body sickly and black. Each target takes 2d6 damage. A successful Fortitude save halves this damage.

Olanim can focus on only one target rather than multiple. If Olanim targets only a single creature with this spell and it fails its save, the target is also staggered for 7 rounds.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT9AigHuJwCTqk9S1J_target
attribs.current: e 10 ft. Square or One Object

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT9AigHuJwCTqk9S1J_description
attribs.current: Olanim covers a solid surface with a layer of slippery grease. Any Creature in the area when the spell is cast must succeed at a Reflex save or fall prone. A Creature can walk within or through the area of grease at half Normal speed with a successful DC 10 Acrobatics check. Failure means the Creature can’t move that round and must then succeed at a Reflex save or fall prone, while failure by 5 or more means it falls prone (see the Acrobatics skill for details). A Creature that doesn’t move on its turn doesn’t need to attempt this check and isn’t considered Flat-Footed. The spell can also be used to create a greasy coating on an item. Unattended material objects are always affected by this spell. If Olanim attempts to affect an Object in a creature’s possession, the Creature can attempt a Reflex save to negate the Effect. If the Creature fails the initial saving throw, it immediately drops the item and must attempt a new save each round it attempts to pick up, hold, or use the item. A Creature wearing greased armour or clothing gains a +5 Circumstance Bonus to Acrobatics checks to Escape a Grapple and a +2 Circumstance Bonus to its AC against Grapple combat manoeuvres.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDT9BnsPrk3QymTZJrN_description
attribs.current:
Olanim touches a Target with a device she's holding that uses electricity, requiring a melee Attack against the target’s EAC. Alternatively, Olanim can instead touch an electrical device a Target is wearing (or a Target that is an electrical device, such as a robot) with her hand, gaining a +2 bonus to her Attack roll. Either way, if Olanim's Attack hits, the electrical device surges out of Control, dealing 4d6 electricity damage to her Target.

Casting this spell doesn’t provoke Attacks of opportunity.

attribs.name: captain

attribs.name: repeating_attack_-NDTYIx1lKTEo8rM7kJe_description
attribs.current:
Point (+8)
A weapon with this special property is always short range and can’t be fired against targets that are outside the first range increment. If a tracking weapon would hit a ship in an arc that contains a weapon with the point special property, the gunner of the targeted starship can attempt an immediate gunnery check with the point weapon against the incoming tracking projectile using the bonus listed in parentheses in the weapon’s Special entry (instead of her usual bonus to gunnery checks). The DC for this gunnery check is equal to 10 + the tracking weapon’s speed. If the attack hits, the tracking weapon is destroyed before it can damage the ship. A point weapon can be used to attempt only one such free gunnery check each round, but this usage potentially allows a point weapon to be fired twice in a single round.

attribs.name: repeating_attack_-NDTYMgeLeoEIXgifEhu_description
attribs.current:
Broad Arc
A weapon with this special property can fire in an arc adjacent to the one in which it was installed with a –2 penalty. A broad arc weapon can fire at only one target at a time.

Mystical
When attempting a gunnery check with a mystical weapon, which is a hybrid device, a gunner can use their ranks in Mysticism in place of either their base attack bonus or ranks in Piloting, and their Wisdom modifier in place of their Dexterity modifier.

Quantum
Once a gunner fires a quantum weapon, he can reroll one gunnery check (see page 243) for that weapon after its launch if the result would be a miss. Only tracking weapons have this special property.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTWQmZztG5um-EJC4d_description
attribs.current: By increasing the security of the starship’s computer, these systems increase the DC to hack into it by 1 (see page 139). This upgrade can be purchased up to four times.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTW59EpuNUVhGPCSHq_description
attribs.current: An arcane laboratory contains all the tools and space necessary to craft magic items (see page 235), though the crafter must still provide the necessary raw materials. Such a laboratory reduces the crafting time by half.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTW78jRdzkRSoZkaIy_description
attribs.current: This specialized gym and miniature arena provides an array of holographic threats, tactical dilemmas, and automated combat simulations that help crew members practice close-quarters tactics and self-defense. This facility also adds several caches of weapons and armor spread throughout the starship, ensuring that the crew always have essential armaments close at hand in the event of an emergency. A basic combat training facility improves the crew’s battle readiness, treating them as skilled (and granting a bonus) when resolving boarding events (page 40).

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTW9EGk5Q2d4EK9JCa_description
attribs.current: Unconverted expansion bays count as cargo holds. A cargo hold can contain approximately 25 tons of goods, with no item being larger than Large. A starship with multiple cargo holds can hold larger objects; usually 4 contiguous cargo holds are required to hold Huge objects and 8 for Gargantuan objects. These size restrictions can be overridden at the GM’s discretion.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTWAFlfZKFf2iwYqI2_description
attribs.current: Starships that function as passenger vessels require spaces apart from their crew quarters for their guests to sleep. A single expansion bay can be converted into common quarters (usually simple bunks or hammocks) for six passengers, good quarters (usually a comfortable bed, a desk with a chair, and a small set of drawers) for four passengers, or luxurious quarters (usually a large bed, a wardrobe, a couch, a desk with a nice chair, and a private washroom) for two passengers.

attribs.name: repeating_system_-NDTWBpOggI3rCo8KI2X_description
attribs.current: A tech workshop contains all the space and tools necessary to craft technological items (see page 235), though the crafter must still provide the necessary raw materials. Such a workshop reduces the crafting time by half.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
Before Combat Dalmar casts reflecting armour on herself and venomous weapon on Maxin’s gun.
During Combat Dalmar stays adjacent to Maxin when possible, so he can use his Bodyguard feat to protect her. She prefers to cast mind thrust or inflict pain, targeting enemies who fail their saving throw with sickening spells (expending 2nd-level slots) and those who succeed with backlash if possible. She uses mindbreaker until out of RP. Dalmar pauses her assault to cast mystic cure on herself or Maxin or dispel magic on a troublesome spell effect. If one of her brother’s dies or surrenders, Dalmar replaces them with a summoned fire or water elemental. When she’s expended her higher-level spell slots, Dalmar targets foes with mental anguish or lesser confusion. If she’s the last fighting Wither, Dalmar switches to her pistol or sword, casting venomous weapon beforehand if she has opportunity.
Morale If one of her siblings is dead, Dalmar fights to the death. Otherwise, she surrenders if reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer.

attribs.current: Gold AbadarCorp Travel Suit, Aphelion Laser Pistol with 2 High-Capacity Batteries (40 Charges each), Tactical Duelling Sword, Mk 3 Ring of Resistance, Spell Gem of Remove Affliction, spell Gem of Tongues, Credstick (5,000 Credits)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY-w2aHkebu3tN0uvL_description
attribs.current: Whenever a foe fails a Will save against one of Dalmar’s spells, she can expend a spell slot of 2nd-level or higher to infect that target with a corrupted contagion. If the spell dealt damage, the spell deals 1d8 additional acid damage per level of the spell slot expended. If the spell didn’t deal damage, that foe becomes sickened for 1 round per level of the spell slot expended.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDXzm9yYVL-pxOb03o4_description
attribs.current: Dalmar links her mind to that of a touched creature to swiftly communicate a large amount of complex information in an instant. Dalmar decides what the target learns, limited to any amount of information that otherwise could be communicated in 10 minutes. This information comes in a series of visual images and emotional sensations, and it isn’t language dependent.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDXzrPDEg5PJwPJHM5c_target
attribs.current: One Creature, Object, Spell, or Spellcaster

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDXzrPDEg5PJwPJHM5c_description
attribs.current:
Dalmar can use dispel magic to end one ongoing spell that has been cast on a Creature or Object, to temporarily suppress the magical Abilities of a magic item, or to counter another spellcaster’s spell. A dispelled spell ends as if its duration had expired. Some Spells, as detailed in their descriptions, can’t be defeated by dispel magic. Dispel magic can dispel (but not counter) spell-like Abilities just as it does Spells. The Effect of a spell with an Instantaneous duration can’t be dispelled.

Dalmar chooses to use dispel magic in one of two ways: as a targeted dispel or as a counter.

Targeted Dispel: One Creature, Object, or spell is the Target of the dispel magic spell. Dalmar can also use a targeted dispel to specifically end one spell affecting the Target or one spell affecting an area (such as Zone of Truth). Dalmar must name the specific spell Effect to be targeted in this way or otherwise uniquely Identify it (such as “that Burning wall” or “the spell that’s giving him those duplicates”). Attempt a dispel check (1d20 + 9) with a DC equal to 11 + the spell’s caster level. If Dalmar succeeds, the spell ends. If Dalmar doesn’t specify a spell and there is more than one possible spell on the Target, her targeted dispel attempts to dispel a spell at random.

If Dalmar Target a force, an Object, or a Creature that is the Effect of an ongoing spell (such as Unseen Servant), she attempts a dispel check to end the spell that conjured the Object or Creature.

If the Object that Dalmar Target is a magic item, she attempts a dispel check against the item level (DC = 11 + the item level). If Dalmar succeeds, all the item’s magical properties are suppressed for [[1d4]] (1d4) rounds, after which the item recovers its magical properties. A suppressed item becomes nonmagical for the duration of the Effect. A magic item’s nonmagical physical properties are unchanged: a suppressed holy laser pistol is still a laser pistol. Artefacts and deities are unaffected by mortal magic such as this.
Dalmar can choose to automatically succeed at her dispel check against any spell she has cast.

Counter: Dalmar can use the energy of dispel magic to disrupt the casting of other Spells. First, select an Opponent and take the ready action to cast dispel magic when that Target casts a spell. This is considered a purely defensive action. When that readied action is triggered, Dalmar casts dispel magic and must attempt a dispel check (1d20 + 9) to counter the other spellcaster’s spell. The DC is equal to 11 + the other spellcaster’s caster level. If the check is successful and the Target is in range, the spell fails and has no result.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDXzsaE9YC92sK2Il80_description
attribs.current:
Dalmar divines the most vulnerable portion of her opponent’s mind and overloads it with a glut of psychic information. The Target can attempt a Will saving throw to halve the damage dealt by this spell. This spell has no Effect on Creatures without an Intelligence score.

1st: When Dalmar casts mind thrust as a 1st-level spell, it deals 2d10 damage to the Target.

2nd: When Dalmar casts mind thrust as a 2nd-level spell, it deals 4d10 damage to the Target.

3rd: When Dalmar casts mind thrust as a 3rd-level spell, it deals 7d10 damage to the Target.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDXzxk2IA-lOfEjUHVt_description
attribs.current: Dalmar telepathically racks the target’s mind and body with agonizing pain that imposes a –2 penalty to Ability Checks, Attack rolls, and Skill Checks. A Target that succeeds at a Will saving throw reduces the duration to 1 round.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDY-0AtEfMzyCudOVHZ_description
attribs.current:
With a touch, Dalmar heals and invigorates her Target, restoring a number of Hit Points. If the Target regains all of its Hit Points as a result of this healing, Dalmar can apply the remaining healing to herself. On the other hand, if this isn’t enough to restore all the target’s Hit Points, Dalmar can transfer any number of her own Hit Points to the Target, healing the Target that Dalmar You can’t transfer more Hit Points than she has or more Hit Points than the Target is missing.

Mystic cure restores a number of Hit Points to Dalmar's Target depending on the spell’s level.

1st: 1d8 + Dalmar's Wisdom Modifier

2nd: 3d8 + Dalmar's Wisdom Modifier

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDY-2jtvEtiZwGFOUTG_description
attribs.current:
This spell summons an Extraplanar Creature (typically an Elemental, Magical Beast Native to another plane, or Outsider, but also occasionally even Extraplanar constructs). The summoned Creature appears where Dalmar designates and acts immediately on her turn. It Attacks Dalmar's opponents to the best of its ability. If Dalmar can communicate with the Creature, he can direct it to not Attack, to Attack particular enemies, or to perform Other Actions.

Dalmar chooses which of the selected Creatures she summons each time she casts the spell.

1st: When Dalmar casts summon Creature as a 1st-level spell, she summons one Creature from her selection of Creatures from the 1st-level Summoning list.

2nd: When Dalmar casts summon Creature as a 2nd-level spell, she summons one Creature from her selection of Creatures from the 2nd-level Summoning list. If the chosen Creature is from a lower-level Summoning list, Dalmar summon three such Creatures instead.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDY-7FvGSHZkvRIgxkn_description
attribs.current: Dalmar touches a weapon that deals bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage and imbue it with poison. The next five attacks made using the weapon are poisoned. Each creature damaged by these attacks must succeed at a Fortitude save or be sickened for 2d4 rounds.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDY-AQQgxvEojp089YI_description
attribs.current:
This spell causes a single Creature to become confused for 1 round, making it unable to determine its actions. A confused Creature that is attacked automatically Attacks or attempts to Attack its attackers on its next turn, as long as it is still confused at the start of its next turn. Note that a confused Creature will not make Attacks of opportunity against any foe that it is not already devoted to Attacking (either because of its most recent action or because it has just been attacked). For a confused Creature that has not been attacked, roll on the following table at the start of the affected creature’s turn each round to see what it does in that round.

D%	Behavior
1-25	Act normally.
26-50	Do nothing but babble incoherently.
51-75	Deal 1d8 + Str Modifier damage to self with item in hand.
76-100	Attack nearest Creature.

A confused Creature that can’t carry out the indicated action does nothing but babble incoherently. Attackers are not at any special advantage when Attacking a confused Target.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDY-D8iKsmxRrYf2mGR_duration
attribs.current: 90 Minutes or Until Dismissed (D); See Text

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-NDY-D8iKsmxRrYf2mGR_description
attribs.current: Dalmar creates a shimmering skin-like coating of mystical force that covers her body, allowing her to reflect damage she takes back against her attacker. At any time during this spell’s duration, when Dalmar takes damage from an Attack made with a weapon by a foe within 100 feet, she can choose to dismiss the spell as a Reaction. If Dalmar does, the armour crackles with energy as it disappears, arcing through the air to strike the Attacking Creature, which takes an amount of force damage equal to the damage dealt to her at the time this spell was dismissed (maximum 10). The Target can attempt a Reflex save for half damage.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY4eNzzMulc35amIRK_description
attribs.current: Dalmar uses her raw will and understanding of the mind’s structure to crush and demoralize her enemies. Dalmar might be a special ops assassin, a psychic interrogator, or a righteous military crusader breaking the enemy’s spirit on the battlefield.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY4jQA9FZiTf8Aa6At_description
attribs.current: Whenever a foe succeeds at a Will save against one of Dalmar's spells and completely negates the effect, that foe takes 9 nonlethal damage. This is a mind-affecting pain effect.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY4zm8qSTX4uE5hqxo_description
attribs.current: As a standard action, Dalmar can spend 1 Resolve Point to create uncertainty in the mind of a foe within 30 feet. Dalmar chooses whether the target becomes flat-footed, becomes off-target, takes a –2 penalty to saving throws, or takes a –2 penalty to skill checks. The effect lasts for 4 rounds, unless the target succeeds at a Will save to reduce the duration to just 1 round. A creature can be affected only by one sow doubt effect. If Dalmar uses this ability on the same creature again, the new effect replaces the old effect. This is a mind-affecting effect.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY5HOaGdM-VWjdbMac_description
attribs.current: As a standard action, Dalmar can tweak the pain centers in the brain of a foe within 60 feet, causing it to suffer intense agony. The target must succeed at a Will save or be nauseated for 1 round. Regardless of the save, the creature becomes immune to this ability for 24 hours. This is a mindaffecting pain effect.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat Maxin begins the fight by activating his energy shield and using miracle worker on his armour. Maxin targets the strongest or most hated PC with superior firepower and attacks that PC with his experimental weapon prototype (a plasma cannon) until they fall, using superior fire power again whenever he switches targets. Maxin uses his Bodyguard feat to protect Dalmar if she’s adjacent to him; he never protects Rosell this way.
Morale If one of his siblings is dead, Maxin fights to the death. Otherwise, he surrenders when reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: White Carbon Skin (Mk 2 Electrostatic Field), Buzzblade Duelling Sword with 2 Batteries (20 Charges each), Seeking Red Star Plasma Cannon with 4 High-Capacity Batteries (40 Charges each), Credstick (5,000 Credits)

attribs.name: repeating_attack_-NDY61vdQOzfTIBnyl-u_description
attribs.current:
Seeking
The seeking fusion causes an attack from a weapon to veer toward its target. This negates any miss chance caused by the target having concealment, though it has no effect on miss chances from other sources (and does not offset the miss chance from a target having total concealment).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY7PrqnC5n5FxmsbB6_description
attribs.current: As a standard action, Maxin can cause a short in an electronic device, including most ranged energy weapons, melee weapons with the powered special property, or a single armour upgrade. This makes the device nonfunctional for 1 round. Overload doesn’t cause a locked door, safe, or other device to open, but it prevents anyone from opening it for 1 round. Maxin must be adjacent to the device to use this ability. If Maxin uses overload on an item or armour upgrade in someone’s possession, the owner can attempt a Reflex saving throw to negate the effect (DC 18). Overload doesn’t affect androids, cybernetics, drones, powered armour, robots, or creatures with the technological subtype (all of which have shielding against this sort of attack), or items larger than Medium. Once a device has been successfully overloaded, a residual static charge prevents that device from being overloaded again for 1 minute.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY7R8nr1Y7FgFFcZya_description
attribs.current: When Maxin attacks with his experimental weapon prototype, he can enhance its damage dealt to select foes. As a move action, Maxin calibrates his weapon prototype to deal additional damage to one enemy he can see. Maxin gains an insight bonus equal to his mechanic level to damage on all attacks against the designated target. Calibrating his weapon against another enemy causes Maxin to immediately lose this bonus against the previous enemy.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat Rosell favors melee combat, either using triple attack or trick attack with Acrobatics and bleeding shot, and using certainty to reroll poor Acrobatics checks. He doesn’t care about his siblings and fights as if he were on his own.
Morale Rosell surrenders if reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY9q7rc7yKIdgjMOUx_description
attribs.current: When Rosell succeeds at both the skill check and attack roll of his trick attack, he can make the target flat-footed or off-target until the beginning of his next turn. Rosell might learn exploits that grant them additional options for his debilitating trick, but he can select only one option each time he hits with a trick attack.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDY9sso2KZWr38aqCN4_description
attribs.current: Rosell can trick or startle a foe and then attack when she drops her guard. As a full action, Rosell can move up to his speed. Whether or not the Rosell moved, he can then make an attack with a melee weapon with the operative special property or with any small arm. Just before making his attack, attempt a Bluff, Intimidate, or Stealth check with a DC equal to 20 + Rosell's target’s CR. If Rosell succeeds at the check, he deals 5d8 additional damage and the target is flat-footed against his attack. Rosell can’t use this ability with a weapon that has the unwieldy special property or that requires a full action to make a single attack.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-NDYAGBHoYLgvZb63WLm_description
attribs.current: When making a full attack using only melee weapons with the operative special property or small arms, Rosell can make up to three attacks instead of two.

attribs.name: repeating_vehicle-modifications_-NECCZGFqPtZIY79Kg6S_description
attribs.current: Some Vehicles have autocontrol, which enables you to spend your actions on tasks other than Piloting, but is far less capable than an Autopilot. You can engage autocontrol as a Swift Action after taking a drive or race action, and it lasts until it is disengaged (also a swift action) or until the vehicle is no longer capable of Moving. When you're using autocontrol, the vehicle becomes uncontrolled, but each round it moves in a straight line for the same distance and at the same heading and speed as the last pilot action (moving as if taking two drive actions if drive was the last action the pilot took, or as a race action if that was the last action the pilot took). The autocontrol uses the result of the pilot's most recent Piloting check as the result of its Piloting checks.
